facts.text: The case is Civil Appeal No. 1695 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1695 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 20, 21, 1967 of the Mysore High Court Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 347 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 20, 21, 1967 of the Mysore High Court Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 347 of 1965.

facts.text: M. Tarkunde and D. N. Mishra appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: M. Tarkunde and D. N. Mishra, for the appellant.

facts.text: P. Rao appeared for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: P. Rao, for the respondents.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by MATHEW, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MATHEW, J.

facts.text: Appellant was operating an iron mine within the State of Mysore on the basis of a lease granted by the State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who was operating an iron mine within the State of Mysore on the basis of a lease granted by the State,

facts.text: Appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court of Mysore challenging the validity of the provisions of the Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Act, Central Act 58 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: filed a writ petition before the High Court of Mysore challenging the validity of the provisions of the Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Act  Central Act 58 of 1961 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended that the Act is violative of article 14 of the Constitution as it imposes a flat rate of excise duty on iron ore without reference to the actual content of iron in the ore.

anchor.surface_text: The companytentions of the appellant in the writ petition were that the Act is violative of article 14 of the Constitution in that it imposes a flat rate of excise duty on iron are without reference to the actual companytent of iron in the ore

facts.text: Appellant contended that there was excessive delegation of legislative power as the power to fix the rate of excise duty was delegated to the government.

anchor.surface_text: and that there was excessive delegation of legislative power in that the power to fix the rate of excise duty was delegated to the government.

facts.text: Prayer in the writ petition was for declaration of invalidity of the Act and quashing the demand made pursuant to the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer in the petition was for a declaration of the invalidity of the Act with the companysequential relief of quashing the demand made in pursuance to the Act.

facts.text: Writ petition was heard along with other similar petitions.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was heard along with other similar petitions.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petitions by a common order.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the writ petitions by a companymon order and this appeal, by special leave, is against the order in so far as it affects the appellant

facts.text: Act brought into force in Mysore State from October 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the Mysore State was companycerned, the Act was brought into force from October 1, 1963.

facts.text: Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Rules 1963 framed and published by notification dated September 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the power companyferred by Section 8, rules called the Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Rules 1963, were framed and published by a numberification dated September 20, 1963.

facts.text: High Court decided first question against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the first question decided against the appellant by the High Court, numberarguments were addressed before us

facts.text: Only point argued before Supreme Court was that section 2 of the Act suffers from excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: The only point argued on behalf of the appellant was that s. 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation in that under that Section the Central Government has been given a blanket power to fix the rate of excise duty.

facts.text: Appellant contended that section 2 provides no guidance, basis or relevant considerations for fixing the rate.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended that the section, while leaving it to the Central Government to fix the rate and change it from time to time, has failed to give sufficient guidance to the Government in the matter of fixing the rate, number has it indicated the basis for fixation or the relevant company- sideration to be taken into account for fixing the rate.

facts.text: High Court negatived the contention relying on Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema AIR 1965 SC 1107.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relying on the decision of this Court in Cor- poration of Calcutta and Another v. Liberty Cinema 1  negatived the companytention. A. I.R. 1965 S. C. 1107.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that section 2 of the Act does not suffer from excessive delegation as there are guidelines in section 3, maximum rate, parliamentary appropriation and reporting requirements.

anchor.surface_text: Tested in the light of the reasoning adopted in the cases referred to above, we are of opinion that the Act has furnished definite guidelines for the government to exercise the power to fix the rate of excise duty. Section 3 has specified the purposes for which the excise duty companylected is to be utilized.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal with companyts.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 20, 21, 1967 of the Mysore High Court Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 347 of 1965.

filed a writ petition before the High Court of Mysore challenging the validity of the provisions of the Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Act Central Act 58 of 1961 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.
and that there was excessive delegation of legislative power in that the power to fix the rate of excise duty was delegated to the government.

concepts.unlisted_description: Delegation without sufficient guidance, policy or standards

anchor.surface_text: The only point argued on behalf of the appellant was that s. 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation in that under that Section the Central Government has been given a blanket power to fix the rate of excise duty.

concepts.unlisted_description: Delegation without sufficient guidance, policy or standards

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the section, while leaving it to the Central Government to fix the rate and change it from time to time, has failed to give sufficient guidance to the Government in the matter of fixing the rate, nor has it indicated the basis for fixation or the relevant consideration to be taken into account for fixing the rate.

concepts.unlisted_description: Delegation without sufficient guidance, policy or standards

anchor.surface_text: With effect from such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint, there shall be levied and collected, as a cess for the purposes of this Act on all iron ore produced in any mine, a duty of excise at such rate not exceeding fifty naye paise per metric tonne of iron ore as the Central Government may, from time to time, fix by notification in the official Gazette.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2, Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Act, 1961
concepts.unlisted_description: Provides for levy of excise duty (cess) on iron ore at a rate to be fixed by Central Government, not exceeding 50 naye paise per metric tonne

anchor.surface_text: An amount equivalent to the proceeds of the duty levied under this Act, reduced by the cost of collection as determined by the Central Government, together with any income from investment of the said amount and any other moneys received by the Central Government for the purposes of this Act, shall, after due appropriation made by Parliament by law, be utilised by the Central Government to meet the expenditure incurred in connection with measures which, in the opinion of that Government, are necessary or expedient to promote the welfare of labour employed in the iron ore mining industry

concepts.interpretation: Specifies purposes for utilisation of cess proceeds, providing guidelines for rate fixation under S.2

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s for each acre of land in a division of the deltaic area and that the imposition of tax on land for raising general revenue is substantially differen

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3, Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Act, 1961
concepts.unlisted_description: Utilisation of cess proceeds for labour welfare in iron ore mining

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the power conferred by Section 8, rules called the Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Rules 1963, were framed and published by a notification dated September 20, 1963.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 8, Iron Ore Mines Labour Welfare Cess Act, 1961

anchor.surface_text: This power flows, in my judgment from art. 246 of the Constitution. The word exclusive means exclusive of any other legislature and not exclusive of any other subordinate body.

concepts.interpretation: Parliament has full power to delegate legislative authority to subordinate bodies under Art. 246

issues.text: Whether the Act is violative of Article 14 of the Constitution in that it imposes a flat rate of excise duty on iron ore without reference to the actual content of iron in the ore

anchor.surface_text: The contentions of the appellant in the writ petition were that the Act is violative of article 14 of the Constitution in that it imposes a flat rate of excise duty on iron are without reference to the actual content of iron in the ore

issues.text: Whether Section 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation in that the Central Government has been given a blanket power to fix the rate of excise duty without sufficient guidance, basis for fixation or relevant considerations

anchor.surface_text: and that there was excessive delegation of legislative power in that the power to fix the rate of excise duty was delegated to the government.

issues.text: Whether s. 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation in that under that Section the Central Government has been given a blanket power to fix the rate of excise duty, having failed to give sufficient guidance to the Government in the matter of fixing the rate, nor indicated the basis for fixation or the relevant consideration to be taken into account for fixing the rate

anchor.surface_text: The only point argued on behalf of the appellant was that s. 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation in that under that Section the Central Government has been given a blanket power to fix the rate of excise duty. It was contended that the section, while leaving it to the Central Government to fix the rate and change it from time to time, has failed to give sufficient guidance to the Government in the matter of fixing the rate, nor has it indicated the basis for fixation or the relevant consideration to be taken into account for fixing the rate.

issues.text: The question for consideration is whether subsequent decisions of this Court have in any way modified or altered the principles laid down in [Liberty Cinema] and if so, to what extent, and whether s. 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether subsequent decisions of this Court have in any way modified or altered the principles laid down in this ruling and if so, to what extent, and whether s. 2 of the Act suffers from the vice of excessive delegation.

arguments.claim: The Act has furnished definite guidelines for the government to exercise the power to fix the rate of excise duty as Section 3 has specified the purposes for which the excise duty collected is to be utilized

anchor.surface_text: Tested in the light of the reasoning adopted in the cases referred to above, we are of opinion that the Act has furnished definite guidelines for the government to exercise the power to fix the rate of excise duty. Section 3 has specified the purposes for which the excise duty collected is to be utilized.

arguments.claim: The purposes mentioned in Section 3 are not vague or indefinite and the expenses to be incurred for those purposes can be calculated with reasonable certainty

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the purposes mentioned are vague or indefinite or that the expenses to be incurred for those purposes cannot be calculated with reasonable certainty.

arguments.claim: The power to levy the duty is limited by the expenses required to discharge the statutory function and the rate fixed should bring in the amount necessary to meet those needs

anchor.surface_text: The power to levy the duty must be taken to be limited by the expenses required to discharge the statutory function to be performed by the delegate and so, the rate that is to be fixed should be such as would bring in the amount necessary to meet the needs of the delegate for discharging the functions.

arguments.claim: Expenditure of collected amount for Section 3 purposes is ensured by parliamentary appropriation by law and publication of accounts and reports in the official Gazette

anchor.surface_text: That the amount collected will be expended for the purposes enumerated in s. 3 is ensured firstly by requiring the Government to make an appropriation by means of parliamentary legislation and secondly, by requiring, accounts and reports to be published in the official Gazette.

arguments.claim: The policy of the Act has been clearly stated, purposes enumerated, and it is possible for the delegate to calculate the amount necessary to meet them providing necessary guidance

anchor.surface_text: The policy of the Act has been clearly stated the purposes for which the tax collected should be expended have been enumerated and the purposes are such that it is reasonably possible for the delegate to calculate the amount necessary to meet them.

arguments.claim: Section 2 fixes a maximum rate so the delegate is not given uncontrolled discretion and the area of discretion is demarcated preventing a blanket power

anchor.surface_text: Quite apart from these circumstances, the fact that s. 2 has fixed the maximum rate would indicate that the delegate is not given an uncontrolled discretion in the matter of fixing the rate. The area within which the discretion has to be exercised having been clearly demarcated, it cannot be said that a blanket power to fix the rate has been delegated to government.

holdings.text: the Act has furnished definite guidelines for the government to exercise the power to fix the rate of excise duty

anchor.surface_text: Tested in the light of the reasoning adopted in the cases referred to above, we are of opinion that the Act has furnished definite guidelines for the government to exercise the power to fix the rate of excise duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents reviewed; S.3 specifies purposes for utilization providing guidance; purposes calculable; limited by expenses, parliamentary appropriation, reports, and maximum rate in S.2

Precedent on sufficient guidelines supports argument confirming validity after reviewing precedents
Precedent upholding delegation with guidelines supports court finding of no excessive delegation
Precedent with guidelines for rate fixation supports holding on definite guidelines

Precedent from Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla Cotton supports the holding by providing analogous reasoning on policy and tax-related delegation, aligning with Wednesbury assessment of relevant considerations.

Precedent (1883 9 AC 117) supports the holding by affirming legislatures' power to delegate without explicit policy or guidance, reinforcing that the Act's stated policy satisfies Wednesbury requirements against ignoring relevant considerations.

Precedent (1885 10 AC 282) supports the holding by confirming power to delegate legislative authority without policy, standard, or guidance, bolstering the finding of reasonable policy in the Act under Wednesbury doctrine.
